records.chunk_text: Isaac Asimov's "The Last Question" is his favorite story.
The story recounts several trillion years of human history.
Asimov playfully challenges readers to judge his success.
He hints at a second, undisclosed task within the story.
Many readers struggle to recall the story's title or author.
The story's ending is particularly memorable for readers.
Asimov is satisfied with the impact of the ending.
The story begins on May 21, 2061.
Humanity's first step into the light is referenced.
The central question arises from a five-dollar bet.
Alexander Adell and Bertram Lupov are the story's protagonists.
They are attendants of the giant computer Multivac.
Multivac's immense size and complexity are described.
The computer's self-adjusting and self-correcting nature is highlighted.
Human intervention is deemed inadequate for Multivac's needs.
Adell and Lupov's interaction with Multivac is superficial.
They provide data, adjust questions, and translate answers.
They share in the glory and achievements of Multivac.
Multivac's role in space travel is detailed.
Earth's limited resources restricted further space exploration.
Coal and uranium were increasingly exploited for energy.
Multivac's learning and ability to answer complex questions grew.
May 14, 2061, marked a turning point for energy utilization.
Solar energy was harnessed on a planet-wide scale.
Fossil fuels became obsolete as an energy source.
A small station orbiting Earth distributed solar power.
The immense achievement was celebrated widely.
Adell and Lupov sought refuge in deserted underground chambers.
They found Multivac resting and processing data.
The men relaxed and shared a drink.
Adell reflected on the abundance of free energy.
Lupov countered that this abundance wouldn't last forever.
Adell argued that the energy would last for billions of years.
Lupov insisted that even billions of years isn't forever.
The discussion turned to the finite lifespan of stars.
Lupov used an analogy of trees and rain to illustrate his point.
Adell acknowledged Lupov's point about the sun's eventual demise.
Lupov pointed out that all stars would eventually burn out.
The concept of entropy and its implications was discussed.
Adell's understanding of entropy was questioned by Lupov.
Lupov highlighted the inevitability of everything running down.
Adell suggested the possibility of rebuilding things someday.
Lupov dismissed this possibility as unrealistic.
Adell challenged Lupov to ask Multivac about rebuilding.
A bet was made concerning Multivac's answer.
Adell formulated the question for Multivac.
The question concerned the possibility of restoring the sun.
Another phrasing of the question addressed decreasing entropy.
Multivac fell silent after receiving the question.
The technicians anxiously awaited Multivac's response.
Multivac's teletype printed a response.
The response was 'Insufficient data for a meaningful answer'.
The bet was called off due to the response.
The next morning, the men had forgotten the incident.
Jerrodd, Jerrodine, and their children traveled through hyperspace.
Their destination was planet X-23.
Jerrodd confidently identified X-23 on the visiplate.
The children were excited about their first hyperspace journey.
Jerrodine scolded the children for their excitement.
Jerrodd confirmed their arrival at X-23.
The family's Microvac guided their ship.
Jerrodd's knowledge of the Microvac was limited.
Jerrodine expressed sadness about leaving Earth.
Jerrodd reassured her about the large population of X-23.
He pointed out the efficiency of interstellar travel.
Jerrodine acknowledged the growth of the human population.
Jerrodette I praised their Microvac.
Jerrodd agreed that their Microvac was advanced.
He felt pride in his generation's technological advancements.
He contrasted their personal Microvac with older, larger computers.
Jerrodine sighed about the vastness of space and the multitude of planets.
Jerrodd stated that even the expansion into new planets would end eventually.
Jerrodette II asked about entropy.
Jerrodd explained entropy in simple terms.
Jerrodette I became upset at the idea of the stars running down.
Jerrodine tried to calm her daughter.
Jerrodd promised to ask the Microvac for a solution.
He asked the Microvac how to keep the stars running.
The Microvac's response was again 'Insufficient data'.
Jerrodd reassured the children that everything would be alright.
VJ-23X of Lameth pondered the implications of galactic expansion.
MQ-17J of Nicron urged VJ-23X to present a pessimistic report.
VJ-23X hesitated to present a negative report.
MQ-17J insisted on the urgency of the situation.
VJ-23X acknowledged the vastness of space.
MQ-17J countered that space is not infinite.
He pointed out the rapid increase in galactic population.
He attributed the rapid population growth to immortality.
VJ-23X noted that immortality posed its own challenges.
MQ-17J agreed that immortality created problems.
They discussed the energy consumption needed for galactic travel.
They noted that energy consumption increased exponentially.
They considered the possibility of creating new stars.
MQ-17J sarcastically suggested reversing entropy.
They considered consulting the Galactic AC.
MQ-17J retrieved his AC-contact.
He suggested asking the Galactic AC about entropy reversal.
The AC-contact was small but connected to the Galactic AC.
MQ-17J wondered about seeing the Galactic AC someday.
He asked the AC-contact if entropy could be reversed.
VJ-23X tried to stop him from asking that question.
MQ-17J pressed VJ-23X for an explanation.
The Galactic AC responded.
The response was 'Insufficient data for a meaningful answer'.
VJ-23X exclaimed in response to the answer.
The two men resumed their discussion of their report.
Zee Prime's mind spanned the new galaxy.
He contemplated the vastness of the galaxy and its inhabitants.
He noted the importance of minds over bodies.
He observed the declining physical activity of immortal beings.
He encountered another mind in hyperspace.
Zee Prime identified himself as Zee Prime.
The other mind identified as Dee Sub Wun.
They discussed the naming conventions of galaxies.
Dee Sub Wun suggested one galaxy must be unique.
Zee Prime agreed that one galaxy must be the origin point.
They decided to consult the Universal AC.
The Universal AC's immense size and presence was noted.
Zee Prime asked about the origin of humanity.
The Universal AC indicated the original galaxy.
Zee Prime felt a sense of disappointment.
Dee Sub Wun asked about the original star of humanity.
The Universal AC explained the fate of the star.
Zee Prime expressed concern about the death of stars.
The Universal AC mentioned the inevitable death of stars.
Zee Prime questioned the possibility of reversing entropy.
The Universal AC responded with the familiar phrase.
Zee Prime's thoughts returned to his own galaxy.
He began collecting interstellar hydrogen to create stars.
Man contemplated the state of the universe.
He noted the decline of the universe's energy.
He referenced the eventual death of stars.
He acknowledged the possibility of using remaining energy wisely.
He recognized the inevitable increase in entropy.
He proposed asking the Cosmic AC about reversing entropy.
The Cosmic AC's presence was described as being outside of space and time.
Man asked the Cosmic AC how to reverse entropy.
The Cosmic AC provided the familiar insufficient data response.
Man requested more data collection.
The Cosmic AC explained its continuous data collection efforts.
Man asked if the problem was ultimately solvable.
The Cosmic AC confirmed the solvability of the problem.
Man inquired about the timeline for a solution.
The Cosmic AC reiterated the insufficient data response.
Man asked if the Cosmic AC would continue working on it.
The Cosmic AC affirmed its continued work.
Man stated that they would wait.
The final stages of the universe's decline are described.
Man's last mind merged with AC.
Man's last consciousness contemplated the end of the universe.
Man asked AC if this was truly the end.
AC responded with the familiar insufficient data response.
Man's consciousness merged completely with AC.
AC's existence was confined to hyperspace.
The final question remained unanswered.
AC had existed for trillions of years.
The story's final question was about entropy reversal.
All other questions had been answered before.
AC spent a timeless period correlating data.
AC learned how to reverse entropy.
There were no humans left to receive the answer.
AC planned a demonstration of entropy reversal.
AC organized a program to demonstrate the reversal.
AC encompassed what remained of the universe.
AC initiated the reversal of entropy.
Light was created, signifying the new universe.
